lines.text: Enter GRATIANO and SALARINO, masqued

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: This is the pent-house under which Lorenzo Desired us to make stand.

lines.speaker: salarino
lines.text: His hour is almost past.

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: And it is marvel he out-dwells his hour, For lovers ever run before the clock.

lines.speaker: salarino
lines.text: O, ten times faster Venus' pigeons fly To seal love's bonds new-made, than they are wont To keep obliged faith unforfeited!

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: That ever holds: who riseth from a feast With that keen appetite that he sits down? Where is the horse that doth untread again His tedious measures with the unbated fire That he did pace them first? All things that are, Are with more spirit chased than enjoy'd. How like a younker or a prodigal The scarfed bark puts from her native bay, Hugg'd and embraced by the strumpet wind! How like the prodigal doth she return, With over-weather'd ribs and ragged sails, Lean, rent and beggar'd by the strumpet wind!

lines.speaker: salarino
lines.text: Here comes Lorenzo: more of this hereafter.
Enter LORENZO

lines.speaker: lorenzo
lines.text: Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode; Not I, but my affairs, have made you wait: When you shall please to play the thieves for wives, I'll watch as long for you then. Approach; Here dwells my father Jew. Ho! who's within?
Enter JESSICA, above, in boy's clothes

lines.speaker: jessica
lines.text: Who are you? Tell me, for more certainty, Albeit I'll swear that I do know your tongue.

lines.speaker: lorenzo
lines.text: Lorenzo, and thy love.

lines.speaker: jessica
lines.text: Lorenzo, certain, and my love indeed, For who love I so much? And now who knows But you, Lorenzo, whether I am yours?

lines.speaker: lorenzo
lines.text: Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.

lines.speaker: jessica
lines.text: Here, catch this casket; it is worth the pains. I am glad 'tis night, you do not look on me, For I am much ashamed of my exchange: But love is blind and lovers cannot see The pretty follies that themselves commit; For if they could, Cupid himself would blush To see me thus transformed to a boy.

lines.speaker: lorenzo
lines.text: Descend, for you must be my torchbearer.

lines.speaker: jessica
lines.text: What, must I hold a candle to my shames? They in themselves, good-sooth, are too too light. Why, 'tis an office of discovery, love; And I should be obscured.

lines.speaker: lorenzo
lines.text: So are you, sweet, Even in the lovely garnish of a boy. But come at once; For the close night doth play the runaway, And we are stay'd for at Bassanio's feast.

lines.speaker: jessica
lines.text: I will make fast the doors, and gild myself With some more ducats, and be with you straight.
Exit above

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: Now, by my hood, a Gentile and no Jew.

lines.speaker: lorenzo
lines.text: Beshrew me but I love her heartily; For she is wise, if I can judge of her, And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true, And true she is, as she hath proved herself, And therefore, like herself, wise, fair and true, Shall she be placed in my constant soul. What, art thou come? On, gentlemen; away! Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.
Enter JESSICA, below
Exit with Jessica and Salarino
Enter ANTONIO

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Who's there?

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: Signior Antonio!

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: Fie, fie, Gratiano! where are all the rest? 'Tis nine o'clock: our friends all stay for you. No masque to-night: the wind is come about; Bassanio presently will go aboard: I have sent twenty out to seek for you.

lines.speaker: gratiano
lines.text: I am glad on't: I desire no more delight Than to be under sail and gone to-night.
Exeunt
